Award.AwardTitle: Self-Organizing Ciliary Beating and its Control in Chlamydomonas
Award.AbstractNarration: In this project the PIs will determine the motor-generated shear forces and doublet sliding in the biciliated unicellular alga Chlamydomonas reinhardtii under wide range of conditions with the goal of establishing the correct mechanism for self-organizing beating structure. First the PIs will record long durations of high temporal and spatial resolution images of ciliary beating using electron-multiplying CCD camera. Next they will determine accurately the drag force exerted by the fluid along the cilium using a slender body theory for low Reynolds number flows. The force generated by motors along the length of a cilium will then be determined by balancing the hydrodynamic drag to internal forces due to sliding and bending. The precise images of the cilia will also allow the PIs to determine the relative sliding of the doublets. The force-sliding data will be used to test various models of self-organizing beating structure as well as to determine the dynamics of the basal body that connects the two cilia to the cell body. The proposed study will add a significant tool for determining the active internal forces generated during ciliary beating. This in-vivo technique will complement the in-vitro molecular genetic, electron microscopy, atomic force microscopy (AFM), and sliding assay techniques currently used to understand the physiology of ciliary beating. Several graduate students will be trained in interdisciplinary research and to work as a team with several advisers. They will participate in all phases including experiment development, data collection, data analysis, and modeling. Undergraduate students will significantly aid the project by characterizing individual ciliary mutants that have mechanical or control function defects and will learn to use AFM. High school students will assist with mutants. The physics of cilia will be incorporated in undergraduate and graduate courses.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Cilia or eukaryotic flagella are 240-nm-diameter (1/400 diameter of human hair) cylindrical protrusions (Fig. 1) from a biological cell. They range in length from 0.005 to 30 mm and are responsible for moving the immersing fluid relative to a biological cell. These "micro hairs" are driven along their length by thousands of tiny motors that facilitate the propagation of traveling waves of bending. The waves look like the waves traveling down a whip, except they are energized all along their length to overcome the energy dissipation of moving the surrounding fluid. They are biological microelectromechanical-systems.

 

 

In mammals cilia provide thrust for sperm, clear dust from lungs, and move fluids through brains. Cilia also play a direct or developmental role in the sensors of fluid flow, light, sound, gravity, smell, touch, temperature and taste. Our first research objective was to evaluate existing self-organized beating (SOB) models for how cilia beat. As data we obtained images of ciliary beating at regular time intervals and determined the hydrodynamic drag force distribution along the cilia. All current SOB models proved inadequate to explain this data. The other and open ended objective was to improve our understanding of how cilia are controlled. Clarifying what is spontaneous SOB behavior and what is control could potentially help understand some ciliopathies which are causes of human diseases.

We have developed a model which well describes the formation of the traveling wave in a specialized region near the base, its propagation that constitutes the active beating of a cilium, its beating frequency, the wavelength of the traveling wave, its amplitude limitation, and its attenuation as it travels. Our hypothesis is that the spontaneous beating is simply a product of the properties of the motors and the viscoelastic spring structures they are embedded in. With clear knowledge of the SOB contribution to ciliary behavior, it has then been possible to characterize ciliary controls. The ciliary parameters have been optimized for a specific range of viscosities in each organism. If the viscosity is too high then the amplitude of the wave decreases rapidly. The tapering of mammalian sperm is a physically necessary adaptation to high viscosity.

Spontaneous SOB is a stable limit cycle, like your heart beat which is limited to a range of beating rates. We found the system uses the strain or potential energy of the wave as the limit to the amplitude of the wave formed at the base. Since the traveling wave is moving a viscous fluid, the energy that might have gone into further increasing its amplitude is dissipated by moving fluid. With this realization it was then possible to characterize the interior springs and the viscoelastic bending in the wave formation region and beyond as the traveling wave propagates.

Consequences of the SOB have been explored. For one, cells have to brake to mate, since swimming is continuous, once they touch they need to stop. Further the same brake may be utilized to fine tune the ballistic-diffusive ratio of swimming, which sets the balance between searching locally or over a wider distance.

Further, the beating itself can be used as a monitor of the cell’s internal ATP. Using this technique the cell was observed to monitor the temporal derivative of light intensity to be able to respond to fluctuations in light intensity on a 100 ms time scale.
